uses: Pain relief and fever reduction for mild to moderate pain such as headache, muscle aches, and menstrual cramps.
dosage: Typical adult oral dose: 325-1000 mg every 4-6 hours as needed; do not exceed 4000 mg per day. Pediatric dosing depends on weight; consult a clinician.
warnings: Liver injury risk increases with higher doses, alcohol use, or underlying liver disease. Check labels to avoid duplicate acetaminophen products.
side_effects: Common: nausea, stomach upset. Rare: serious skin reactions.

uses: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) for pain, inflammation, and fever.
dosage: Typical adult oral dose: 200-400 mg every 4-6 hours as needed; do not exceed 1200 mg per day OTC. Pediatric dosing depends on weight; consult a clinician.
warnings: May increase risk of stomach bleeding, kidney issues, and cardiovascular events. Avoid combining with other NSAIDs. Take with food if stomach upset occurs.
side_effects: Common: upset stomach, heartburn, dizziness. Serious: stomach bleeding, kidney issues, allergic reactions.

uses: Penicillin-class antibiotic for susceptible bacterial infections (e.g., ear, sinus, throat, lower respiratory, urinary tract).
dosage: Typical adult oral dose varies by infection: 500 mg every 8 hours or 875 mg every 12 hours are common regimens; pediatric dosing based on weight and infection severity.
warnings: May cause allergic reactions (including anaphylaxis) especially in patients with penicillin allergy. Overuse may lead to resistance; complete full course as prescribed.
side_effects: Common: diarrhea, rash, nausea. Serious: severe allergic reactions, Clostridioides difficile-associated diarrhea.
